item.title: Complex Numbers
item.description: A complex Number is a number of the form:where: is the name of the complex number is a real value is an Imaginary value ( by itself is a real value) and (so ) where: is the name of the complex number is the magnitude of the vector is the phase angle where: Simply another way to view the polar coordinate This is because it relies on Euler's Formula: A Complex number is best to be thought of as a point or vector on a plane, NOT a "real value + Imaginary value" Think of the horizontal axis as the Real numbers Think of the Vertical Axis as the Imaginary axis Example: means 4 to the right, 3 up. This means that for example, using the magnitude of the vector, and can help you find the real number and the imaginary number! or Rectangular form is easier to use with addition and subtraction of complex numbers, whilst polar is easier with multiplication and division (of course these aren't the only uses though).if we are given: Step 1: Step 2: Step 3: @ Quadrant @ Quadrant @ Quadrant @ Quadrant if we are given: use: so: Short Rule of thumbGiven: Addition: Subtraction:Given: Result:Given:Result: If: then: If: then: polar: If: then:
